passage_content: Shopping time refers to the time a customer spends in one store. The scatterplot above shows the average shopping time, in minutes, of customers at 26 different stores offering various discounts. The line of best fit is also shown.

subject: Math
passage_content: Researchers must conduct an experiment to see whether a new vaccine is effective in relieving certain allergies. They have selected a random sample of 100 allergy patients. Some of the patients are assigned to the new vaccine while the rest are assigned to the traditional treatment.
question_stem: Which of the following methods of assigning each patient's treatment is most likely to lead to a reliable conclusion about the effectiveness of the new vaccine?
option_a: Females are assigned to the new vaccine.
option_b: Those who have more than one allergy are assigned to the new vaccine.
option_c: The patients divide themselves evenly into two groups. A coin is tossed to decide which group receives the new vaccine.
option_d: Each patient is assigned a random number. Those with an even number are assigned to the new vaccine.

subject: Math
passage_content: A basketball manufacturer selects a random sample of its basketballs each week to ensure a consistent air pressure within them is maintained. In Week 1, the sample had a mean air pressure of 8.2 psi (pounds per square inch) and a margin of error of 0.1 psi. In Week 2, the sample had a mean air pressure of 7.7 psi and a margin of error of 0.3 psi.
question_stem: Based on these results, which of the following is a reasonable conclusion?
option_a: Most of the basketballs produced in Week 1 had an air pressure under 8.2 psi, whereas most of the basketballs produced in Week 2 had an air pressure under 7.7 psi.
option_b: The mean air pressure of all the basketballs produced in Week 1 was 0.5 psi more than the mean air pressure of all the basketballs produced in Week 2.
option_c: The number of basketballs in the Week 1 sample was more than the number of basketballs in the Week 2 sample.
option_d: It is very likely that the mean air pressure of all the basketballs produced in Week 1 was less than the mean air pressure of all the basketballs produced in Week 2.
explanation_ai_enhanced: The correct answer cannot be determined without the answer key.

subject: Math
passage_content: The length of a blue-spotted salamander's tail can be used to estimate its age. A biologist selects 80 blue-spotted salamanders at random and finds that the average length of their tails has a 95% confidence interval of 5 to 6 inches.
question_stem: Which of the following conclusions is the most appropriate based on the confidence interval?
option_a: 95% of all blue-spotted salamanders have a tail that is between 5 and 6 inches in length.
option_b: 95% of all salamanders have a tail that is between 5 and 6 inches in length.
option_c: The true average length of the tails of all blue-spotted salamanders is likely between 5 and 6 inches.
option_d: The true average length of the tails of all salamanders is likely between 5 and 6 inches.
explanation_ai_enhanced: The correct answer cannot be determined without the answer key.

subject: Math
passage_content: An economist conducted research to determine whether there is a relationship between the price of food and population density. He collected data from a random sample of 100 U.S. cities and found significant evidence that the price of food is lower in places with a high population density.
question_stem: Which of the following conclusions is best supported by these results?
option_a: In U.S. cities, there is a positive association between the price of food and population density.
option_b: In U.S. cities, there is a negative association between the price of food and population density.
option_c: In U.S. cities, a decrease in the price of food is caused by an increase in the population density.
option_d: In U.S. cities, an increase in the population density is caused by a decrease in the price of food.
explanation_ai_enhanced: The correct answer cannot be determined without the answer key.
